data.title: Hop Power Players: Billboardâ€™s 2023 List of Executives Revealed
data.meta_description: Billboard's 2023 R&B/Hip-Hop Power Players list â€” honoring the executives setting the bar throughout the genres â€” is led by gamma founder Larry Jackson.
data.text:
Larry Jackson

Founder, gamma

In February, TikTokâ€™s 1 billion-plus users received an unexpected gift for Valentineâ€™s Day: exclusive access to the catalog of one of hip-hopâ€™s most revered labels, Death Row Records. Snoop Dogg had purchased the catalog in 2022 and pulled it from streaming services. So the only place to hear tracks from Snoopâ€™s classic Doggystyle or 2Pacâ€™s 10-times-platinum All Eyez on Me was TikTok.

This partnership â€” as unusual as it was savvy â€” was the handiwork of veteran music executive Larry Jackson, 42, who seized the attention of the industry this year when he launched his entertainment company, gamma. Backed by $1 billion in financing and focused on putting that capital to work â€œin particular and acutely on Black culture,â€ Jackson has created a deep-pocketed alternative to the major labels.

Read Billboard â€™s full profile on executive of the year Larry Jackson here.

Sheâ€™yaa â€œ21 Savageâ€ Abraham-Joseph

Justin â€œMeezyâ€ Williams

Co-founders, Slaughter Gang Entertainment

Williams, who began managing 21 Savage in 2015, heads up Slaughter Gang Entertainment, the label he co-founded with the Billboard Hot 100-topping rapper. A highlight of the past year, he says, has been â€œbuilding our new artistsâ€ and seeing those who have begun to make waves get bigger, including 21 Lil Harold, Yung Sinn, SG Tip, Big Bratt and Kid Hazel. Williams is also proud of the companyâ€™s work â€œexecutive-producing and co-distributing the Freaknik soundtrack for the Hulu documentary,â€ an album that accompanies the movie about students from historically Black colleges and universities attending Atlantaâ€™s annual spring break party.

Tunji Balogun

Chairman/CEO, Def Jam Recordings

LaTrice Burnette

Executive vp, Def Jam Recordings; president, 4th & Broadway

Archie Davis

Executive vp/chief creative officer, Def Jam Recordings

Natina Nimene

Executive vp of promotion and artist relations, Def Jam Recordings

Naim McNair

Noah Preston

Executive vps of A&R, Def Jam Recordings

â€œOur journey over the last 18 months has been about establishing this company as an agile, insightful and powerful engine for artist development,â€ says Balogun. The label chief goes on to cite recent Grammy Award winner Muni Long; Coco Jones and her first Mainstream R&B/Hip-Hop Airplay No. 1, â€œICUâ€; and rising rapper Armani White. â€œTogether with the bold A&R work and development around artists like Fridayy, Adekunle Gold and Chase Shakur, these artists represent a super diverse cross-section of the culture,â€ he adds, â€œand are the future lifeblood of Def Jam.â€

Katina Bynum

Executive vp of East Coast labels for urban, Universal Music Enterprises

Bynum captures a professional highlight of the past year in one word: â€œRihanna.â€ The singerâ€™s headlining performance at the Super Bowl LVII halftime show in February was preceded by the 2022 release of the Black Panther: Wakanda Forever soundtrack, which featured Rihannaâ€™s latest song, â€œLift Me Up.â€ The album reached No. 1 on the Soundtracks chart. Following the Super Bowl performance, â€œRihannaâ€™s overall catalog received a huge boost [both in] audio and video streams,â€ says Bynum, pushing â€œher total streams to an all-time high.â€

Juan â€œDJ Kast Oneâ€ Cabral

Associate director of A&R, Legacy Recordings

Cabral has built a solid rep spinning hip-hop, R&B and reggae as DJ Kast One at WQHT (Hot 97) New York, â€œwhere hip-hop lives,â€ as the stationâ€™s slogan goes. As associate director of A&R at Legacy Recordings, the Bronx native works with content, marketing and digital teams to identify trends and elevate â€œmusic that can help refresh and revitalize catalog assets,â€ he says. For example, he assigned and oversaw mixings for Miguelâ€™s â€œSure Thingâ€ and Ruth Bâ€™s â€œDandelionsâ€ and applied Dolbyâ€™s Atmos spacial audio technology to Run-D.M.C.â€™s catalog albums and Khalidâ€™s American Teen for its fifth-anniversary campaign.

Don Cannon

Leighton â€œLakeâ€ Morrison

Tyree â€œDJ Dramaâ€ Simmons

Co-founders, Generation Now

Generation Now enjoyed another fruitful year courtesy of stars Lil Uzi Vert and Jack Harlow. In February, Uzi scored his seventh top 10 on the Hot 100 with his Jersey club hit, â€œJust Wanna Rock,â€ which also reached No. 1 on the Hot Rap Songs chart after its adoption as an anthem for the Philadelphia Eaglesâ€™ Super Bowl run. Harlow netted his third top 10 on the Billboard 200 and first No. 1 on Top Rap Albums with Jackman. He also evolved into a TV darling, starring in the modern-day remake of the 1990s cult classic White Men Canâ€™t Jump and appearing in Lil Dickyâ€™s FX comedy series, DAVE. â€œThis year, we took Generation Now to a whole new level,â€ says Morrison. â€œWe are most proud of all our work in Atlanta to better the community and empower the youth while continuing to push the culture forward and create opportunity.â€

Steve â€œSteve Oâ€ Carless

President of A&R, Warner Records

Dionnee Harper

Warner Records found a rising hip-hop star this year in signee NLE Choppa, who notched two gold singles with â€œSlut Me Outâ€ and his 2 Rare collaboration â€œDo It Again.â€ In addition, the Memphis rapper achieved success on both radio and the road, landing two top 10 singles this year on both the Mainstream R&B/Hip-Hop Airplay and Rhythmic Airplay charts and making over 30 high school and college visits across the country. In June, Choppa was a featured artist at the WHTA (Hot 107.9) Birthday Bash in Atlanta.

R&B and hip-hop flourished as genres at Capitol Music Group and Motown over the past year with breakthroughs from rising stars like Doechii and Toosii as well as Ice Spice, who landed four tracks in the Hot 100 top 10. â€œWe have incredibly talented artists in the pipeline,â€ says Wharton, â€œand Capitol Music Group will continue to prove to the world that we are a real force in these genres.â€

Vp/co-head of urban music, Arista Records

Vp of A&R/co-head of urban music, Arista Records; president, producer, songwriter, Sam Edmonds Songs

For Freeman and Riddick-Tynes, the success of the past year has been largely defined by Aristaâ€™s newest slate of artists. Along with the continued rise of acts like Idman and Audrey Nuna, they both emphasize the introduction of Lola Brooke as a major highlight of 2023, thanks to her breakout success with â€œDonâ€™t Play With It,â€ the burgeoning rapperâ€™s first Hot 100 entry. Says Freeman: â€œSeeing all the adoration and critical acclaim Lola has received from fans, peers and critics as well as the worldwide success she has achieved so far has been an exciting experience.â€

Atlanticâ€™s deep-rooted commitment to artist development has continued to pay off. On the heels of recent success with projects from Burna Boy (â€œLast Lastâ€), Kodak Black (â€œSuper Gremlinâ€) and Ravyn Lenae (â€œSkin Tight,â€ her first No. 1 on Adult R&B Airplay, featuring Steve Lacy), the label dialed up attention with Kaliâ€™s â€œArea Codes.â€ Signed to Atlantic during the pandemic, the rap newcomer achieved her first Hot 100 hit with the TikTok-driven track, which peaked at No. 33. â€œWith the success of â€˜Area Codes,â€™ â€ says Gaba, â€œwe are incredibly excited about breaking yet another new artist.â€

EMPIREâ€™s standing as a champion of its hometown Bay Area hip-hop scene was bolstered once again by the release of The Great Escape from Larry June and The Alchemist, which reached No. 32 on the Billboard 200 and prefaced a 60-city North American headline tour that Etminan calls â€œa great example of an independent artist carving out their own lane.â€ Detroit MC Peezy also reached a career best with the single â€œ2 Million Up,â€ which earned a BET Award nomination and an RIAA gold certification.

Yo Gotti

Founder/CEO, Collective Music Group

The Tennessee rapper and label executiveâ€™s imprint enjoyed a big year, with new signee GloRilla establishing herself as a hot new artist. Named to XXLâ€™s 2023 Freshman Class after scoring Hot 100 hits with â€œF.N.F. (Letâ€™s Go)â€ (with Hitkidd) and â€œTomorrow 2â€ (with Cardi B), she and fellow CMG artist Moneybagg Yo recently hit the chart with â€œOn Wat U On.â€ Meanwhile, their labelmates 42 Dugg, EST Gee, Blac Youngsta, Mozzy and R&B singer Lehla Samia continued to build careers. â€œEveryone on the team plays a part in the win,â€ Gotti told Billboard in 2022. â€œThatâ€™s why itâ€™s called Collective Music Group.â€

Elliot Grainge

Founder/CEO, 10K Projects

Zach Friedman

Tony Talamo

Co-presidents, 10K Projects

â€œHip-hop remains the foundation of everything weâ€™ve built at 10K over these past few years,â€ says Grainge, who applauds Trippie Reddâ€™s ability to â€œpush the creative envelope with his amazing work,â€ including his latest album, Mansion Musik, which peaked at No. 3 on the Billboard 200. Meanwhile, hot new signee Ice Spice â€œhas emerged as one of the biggest artists of the year,â€ Grainge adds, with four top 10 hits on the Hot 100, including the No. 7 debut of â€œBarbie Worldâ€ (see story, page 60).

Naji Grampus

Vp of streaming and strategy, The Orchard

Grampus recently entered a new partnership between The Orchard and his own label, 24/8 Music Group. The joint venture is dedicated to developing hip-hop and R&B artists and â€œreinforces The Orchardâ€™s mission to be a true home for creators,â€ Grampus says. The Orchard also signed Diddyâ€™s Love Records and led release strategies for Nasâ€™ Kingâ€™s Disease III â€” which debuted at No. 10 in November on the Billboard 200, tying Nas with Jay-Z for the most top 10 albums on the chart by a rapper â€” and Lojayâ€™s â€œMonalisaâ€ (with Sarz and Chris Brown), which reached No. 8 on the U.S. Afrobeats Songs chart. â€œWe have seen tremendous success,â€ Grampus says, â€œwith Human Re Sourcesâ€™ breakout artist RAYE and DJ Premierâ€™s Hip Hop Volume 1 in partnership with Mass Appeal as well as Stomp Down Recordsâ€™ Houston-born rapper Monaleo.â€

The relaunch of iconic label Uptown Records underscores Republicâ€™s commitment to R&B/hip-hop music and culture. â€œThe Uptown team, led by Harraway and [fellow co-president] Marleny Reyes, has done a phenomenal job at this early stage building and supporting a roster of incredible artists who speak to the legacy of the label, yet represent the future of our business,â€ says Price. Republic is also home to The Weeknd, Drake, Nicki Minaj, newly minted Songwriters Hall of Fame honoree Post Malone and up-and-comer Coi Leray, as well as hip-hop producer ATL Jacob and his Wicked Money Family label.

300 Entertainment remains a significant force in hip-hop with artists like Megan Thee Stallion, Gunna and Young Thug. Despite its rap-heavy roster, the label also scored big in R&B when Mary J. Blige notched six Grammy Award nominations for this yearâ€™s ceremony, including an album of the year nod. Younger stars flourish, notably PinkPantheress, who scored her first Hot 100 top five song alongside Ice Spice with their â€œBoyâ€™s a Liar, Pt. 2â€ collaboration. 300 has also built out other divisions, including 300 Publishing, Sparta and 300 Studios, which recently won a sports Emmy Award for its debut project, Race. 300 Entertainment co-presidents Bass and Bouab both say that the past year shows the label can operate at a high level in multiple aspects of the business.

â€œNimbleâ€ was the key word for Blac Noize! Recordings in 2022, says McCoy, with the breakout success of rapper GloRillaâ€™s Hitkidd-produced smash, â€œF.N.F. (Letâ€™s Go).â€ McCoy says that being â€œfast and using the incredible amount of data we have todayâ€ has led the company to become an industry leader. â€œTaking â€˜F.N.F.â€™ to No. 1 at [R&B/hip-hop] radio and being nominated for a Grammy after being told it was â€˜regionalâ€™ highlighted a great year,â€ he says.

Cole) and No. 2 on the Hot 100. Alamo has also had significant growth over the past year thanks to the launch of its artist and label services company, Santa Anna, Jones says. She notes that Alamoâ€™s focus with the division, led by president Lee Lâ€™Heureux, â€œis to partner with entrepreneurs in building their businesses,â€ citing team-ups with Conor Ambroseâ€™s Listen to the Kids, Caroline â€œBarolineâ€ Diazâ€™s Great Day and Laka Filmsâ€™ No More Heroes and Now and Forever as â€œjust the beginning.â€

Vp of A&R, APG

APG scored a hit with the skillfully marketed Fast X soundtrack. After securing Jimin of BTS for a feature on Kodak Black and NLE Choppaâ€™s â€œAngel Pt. 1â€ (Muni Long and JVKE are also featured), the album debuted atop the Soundtracks chart. The past year for APG has also included wins in artist development with Lambo4oe and Chase B, as well as Anti Da Menace, Sdot Go and Sweepers ENT, â€œwho have an incredible movement breaking out of New York,â€ and Odetari, â€œwho combines hip-hop and electronic music out of Houston,â€ says Nolan.

RCA has remained a dominant R&B/hip-hop player thanks to a powerful roster that includes Steve Lacy, SZA, Latto and Miguel. SZAâ€™s highly anticipated SOS spent 10 weeks at No. 1 on the Billboard 200, while the single â€œKill Billâ€ logged a record-breaking 21 weeks atop the Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs chart. Miguelâ€™s single â€œSure Thing,â€ resurrected by TikTok over a decade after its 2010 release, reached a new Hot 100 peak at No. 11 and broke the record for most weeks on Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs. Lattoâ€™s â€œPut It on Da Floor Againâ€ with Cardi B reached No. 6 on Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs. Lacy won the best progressive R&B album Grammy for Gemini Rights, home to the Hot 100 No. 1 â€œBad Habit.â€ Pitts says RCA is â€œlooking toward the next wave of rising talent,â€ with Afrobeats signee Libianca already earning her first Hot 100 entry with the single â€œPeople.â€

Vp of label development and marketing, ADA Worldwide

During the past 18 months, ADA Worldwide â€” the independent label and artist services division of Warner Music Group â€” has scored success on several fronts in R&B and hip-hop. The company made Mobb Deep rapper Prodigyâ€™s solo catalog available on streaming services for the first time in three years. Plus, it distributed indie label Big.Ass.Kidsâ€™ compilation See You Next Year â€” a collaboration with new-music curator Pigeons & Planes and executive-produced by Grammy-winning engineer Mike Dean â€” and French rapper Menace Santanaâ€™s album Into the Dark. â€œADA has fueled record-breaking results of emerging talents globally and been instrumental in pivotal cultural moments,â€ says Pope.

Nice Lifeâ€™s profile rose with the globe-spanning success of Lizzo. Between scoring a No. 1 Hot 100 smash with â€œAbout Damn Timeâ€ and earning both a Grammy for record of the year and her first Adult R&B Airplay No. 1 with the SZA collaboration â€œSpecial,â€ Lizzoâ€™s wins over the past 12 months have led to historic success for the label. But Wade says thereâ€™s plenty more in the works from Nice Life: â€œWeâ€™re very excited for whatâ€™s ahead, bolstered by new label signings, including Tinashe, and other developments within the company.â€

Epic has a deep roster of R&B and hip-hop stars, including Travis Scott, 21 Savage, Real Boston Richey and Future, whose ninth album, I Never Liked You, topped the Billboard 200. â€œI have been lucky enough to work every Future album since Pluto and to be a part of so many No. 1s, including this one, his eighth, [which] will of course be a career highlight,â€ Donnarumma says. The Drake- and Tems-assisted single â€œWait for Uâ€ debuted atop the Hot 100 in May 2022 to become Futureâ€™s first No. 1 as a lead artist and spent a record-breaking 16 weeks at No. 1 on the Mainstream R&B/Hip-Hop Airplay chart.

Virgin recently scored a major success with Nigerian artist Rema, whose single â€œCalm Downâ€ with Selena Gomez hit No. 3 on the Hot 100 in June â€” a major feat for an African act. Elsewhere, rapper NFâ€™s latest album, Hope, debuted at No. 2 on the Billboard 200 in April, marking his fourth consecutive top three entry on the chart. â€œWe are lucky to work with the most incredible label partners on the planet and a Virgin team that has so much love and respect for one another,â€ Saturn says.

Snoop Dogg

Owner, Death Row Records

In February 2022, Snoop Dogg announced he had acquired Death Row Records â€” which released his 1993 multiplatinum debut, Doggystyle, and his follow-up albums â€” from MNRK Music Group. Then, in December, he sold a stake in the catalog to gamma, a new company led by former Apple Music executive Larry Jackson. â€œIâ€™ve been in the game for more than two decades. Iâ€™m blessed,â€ Snoop says. â€œIâ€™ve been able to do a lot in this game and in the recent past. Iâ€™m proud of bringing Death Row Records home. Weâ€™ve accomplished a lot since I took ownership, and itâ€™s only going up from here.â€

In May, independent R&B star Brent Faiyaz, who has over 1 billion on-demand streams so far this year, announced that he had partnered with UnitedMasters as well. Taken together, Melhado says, these wins indicate that UnitedMasters is â€œwell positioned to support artists at every phase of their journey.â€

QCâ€™s standout accomplishments from the past year include its merger with HYBE; the release of Lil Babyâ€™s third album, Itâ€™s Only Me, and the Prime Video documentary Untrapped: The Story of Lil Baby; the release of Lil Yachtyâ€™s psychedelic rock album, Letâ€™s Start Here; the launch of Yung Miamiâ€™s REVOLT talk show, Caresha Please; and the development of newer acts like Duke Deuce, Lakeyah and Gloss Up. â€œThereâ€™s too much to name,â€ Mitchell adds, â€œbut itâ€™s always about staying on track with discovering what is out there and growing what we have.â€

Thomas has also been named Billboard â€™s first R&B/Hip-Hop Power Playersâ€™ Choice Award recipient. Read more here.

LVRNâ€™s management side has continued to raise the bar with its clientsâ€™ success stories, beginning with Davidoâ€™s fourth studio album, Timeless, which peaked at No. 2 on the World Albums chart.
